title-group.article-title: On Irregular Prime Power Divisors of the Bernoulli Numbers

abstract.p: Let $B_n (n = 0,1,2,...)$ denote the usual nth Bernoulli number. Let l be a positive even integer where l = 12 or l ≥ 16. It is well known that the numerator of the reduced quotient $\left| {B_l /l} \right|$ is a product of powers of irregular primes. Let (p,l) be an irregular pair with $B_l /l \ne B_{l + p - 1} /(l + p - 1)\bmod p^2 $ . We show that for every r ≥ 1 the congruence $B_{m_r } /m_r \equiv o\bmod p^r $ has a unique solution $m_r $ where $m_r \equiv l\bmod p - 1$ and $l \le m_r < (p - 1)p^{r - 1} $ . The sequence $l \le m_r < (p - 1)p^{r - 1} $ defines a p-adic integer $X_{(p,l)} $ which is a zero of a certain p-adic zeta function $\zeta _{p,l} $ originally defined by T. Kubota and H. W. Leopoldt. We show some properties of these functions and give some applications. Subsequently we give several computations of the (truncated) p-adic expansion of $X_{(p,l)} $ for irregular pairs $x(_{p,\,l} )$ with p below 1000.
